												Quick review of the game since I just completed it.Overall a 7/10 for me.I'll take a look at the gameplay/combat, graphics, story and miscellaneous things.Gameplay/Combat: (8/10)Since it's a story driven game you will sometimes find yourself in cities going around talking to various people instead of just randomly bashing in the skull of everything you see.The dialogues are well done, whilst the actors look like blinking statues most of the time. One thing that bothered me the most about this is that in some cases cutscenes look like normal dialogue and then you end up skipping the whole cutscene instead of the one line you already read.Combatwise it is a very fun game. You have 4 skilltrees to choose from, while you are able to fully spec about 2-3 of them depending on you enjoying the game or only doing the main missions.The skilltrees are divided as follows:Ares: Highly offensive berserker (focused on dealing damage and regenerating health)Hermes: Offensive trickster (focused on dealing damage and dodging)Apollo: Defensive melee tank (focused on blocking damage and regenerating health)Athena: Offensive "godpower"-juggler (focused on dealing damage and using skills)Each of the skilltrees provide quite a unique experience after starting the game, whilst you end up with 2-3 skilltrees filled at the end of the game.The combat is intuitive, while the hitboxes of some enemies are constructed in a way that you mostly will push the enemy away rather than hitting them.But the thing that bothered me the most about this were the invisible walls that are immediatly thrown at you as soon as you start a fight. Oh, you see a region more suited to fight these enemies? Nope, invisible wall.Most of them aren't placed that bad and you won't even find them except you really try to run away from the fight.Keep in mind: Best experience is with a gamepad/controller like with every hack and slash game out there. Graphics: (6/10) Yes, I know what you will say know. Oh my god, are you judging the graphics by todays standards while the game was released in 2008? No I don't.Basically the games graphics for todays standards are poop. For the standards of 2008 they are ok and it is still enjoyable today.Although a big minus is that the only actual graphics setting that it has is the ability to change its resolution.In the game you will also find a lot of things that will kill immersion. Like guards opening gates by touching them rather than pulling a lever or at least pushing some kind of button.Then the games regions are sometimes divided by gates that take a very long time to open. I don't know if it's an intentional "interactive" loading screen or just there to annoy the player.Also some walls have very odd hitboxes, so you'll sometimes be caught on corners or can't get somewhere where you actually should be able to get to (nothing gamebreaking). Same thing applies to nearly every npc you'll encounter.Story: (7/10) I won't include any spoilers here, but some hints to what it is about. So don't read this part if you don't want to know anything about it.The game is pretty straightforward when it comes to the story. As you probably can see from the screenshots it is inspired by the greek mythology, although not at all accurate.There is one twist in it and it really is predictable.It's your standard "perfect world - oh here's a villain - rescue your girl - be happy and marry her while you forget everyone that died for it".Miscellaneous stuff: (No rating here) Here just some stuff I noticed while playing.You can add 2 followers to your group. You'll have 4 available in total.There are no collectibles except for armor and weapons you'll eventually find while progressing in the story.Your dialogue choices don't matter.You will get overpowered at some point. The difficulty curve is just ridiculous.Gameplay adds up to about 8-12 hours. Maybe rushing through it can be even quicker.All in all I'd recommend this game to everyone that likes a pretty standard hack and slash game with a pretty standard story inspired by the greek mythology. I certainly had my fun and I'd buy it again.If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up so other people can see it too.

												Rise of the Argonauts Review General Score : 7/10 Worth playing ? : YesReplay value : Yes, but not for me.  Be warned that I played the whole game using a gamepad, and I do not consider any other way to play such games if not with an xbox controller or game pad. On the combat part of the game, because of this, your mileage may vary in contrast to mine. Perfect example of one good game, that is a victim of it's own ambitions, but at least for me, this time, it is a positive thing. Sometimes you can use Metacritic as a external support for your own conclusions: Critic score:59 User score:7.2 You know why ??, because many of the players that reviewed the game on Metacritic and myself ,had the balls to hold up and finish the game, not like  those "critics" that gave the game a 59. Let aside the "twists" developers did on Greek mythology to build up the game, it excels on the story itself, voice acting and companions.The message of humility, courage, wisdom, discipline and justice (Athena's virtues) spread all along the game's story, combined with other's Greek gods good and bad virtues, is just a great teaching for everyone. Hell,close to the ending of the game, developers even let you go over Greek mythology on the creation of the world  and all living things.Through all the game, I was amazed how the selfish and particular desire of Jason (to revive his dead wife) was coped , mixed and contrasted with all this mythology, where serving the others and acting for the greater good above our own desires is the goal.The first 8 hours of the game, I must admit that there is too much of dialog and too little on action. The dialog system is smart, every dialog option you take is tied to a different god,  so it's an alignment system. The way you think, the way you respond to dialogs, aligns you more with one of other Greek god(s). All the deeds you achieve, via combat, quests, achievements or dialogs can be praised to a different god,thus, giving you access to different buffs and abilities trees. First 8 hours of the game, this buffs and abilities might no seem much of a change, but later on, it is.I specialized on Athena's (my favorite deity, of all there are) and the lighting - powers I got where an amazing spectacle on combat. Combat pretty much is an arena combat, you get on a closed area, and fight your way out.There are puzzles to be solved both in combat situations, and in normal quest situations.  3 different combat styles, really cool all of them. Sword, Mace and Spear.Amazing usage of the shield ,and the shield charge against enemies to open up defenses. The combat in general is really good, but at the second half of the game , it just rocks the boat. Gods powers on combat are just the ice on the cake. Companions are pretty useless on combat (unless you buff them al lot via skill trees), but all of them have great personality, characterizations and dialogs. You choose 2 of them to go with you , on different places. So first half of the game, gets you into the plot with a lot of dialog, backtracking,some lackluster quests an little combat...... This is where I think most of the people quit playing the game.Second part of the game, just gets better and better until there is no effort in continuing playing the game. I must admit, that I managed to pass the first 6 hours because I like a lot Greek and Roman mythology, and I was thrilled with the game's plot, twists on the Jason story overall and with the general message on the game.The scenarios are great and graphics are OK, besides some half♥♥♥♥♥job on some NPCs.The fact there is no direct access to the map (you have to navigate menus to it) just makes me want to punch someone on the face.

												It is an interesting take on the Greek myths and an excellent action-rpg.  It doesn't retell the stories of the characters we know from the Greek myths, but instead weaves a new tale that showcases those legends.  It's very much the Greek Mythos version of Jade Empire.  You begin the game as King Jason of Iolcus.  He sails the seas on the Argo, a large mechanical ship, and in the course of adventuring acquires new party and crew members (the Argonauts of the title).  Be aware:  the first 20-30 mins of the game is pretty bad, but once you speak to the gods, gain their boons and get to the Argo, the game gets progressively better.As this is an action RPG, almost all of the combat takes place in real-time in set encounters as you travel.  It's very much a button-masher/clicker.  There are no random encounters, there is no strategizing, there is no pausing and giving orders to comrades in arms.  The fighting system isn't too complicated, but the experience and skill system sure is puzzling.  You don't acquire experience points from kills or quests completed, like is typical in RPGs, you instead acquire "aspects" by gaining titles that build on your legend (killing X number of enemies, killing in a particular style X number of times, certain dialogue options that appease a specific deity, slaying a particular enemy, etc.) with which you can "spend" at shrines by devoting them to one of four deities:  Apollo, Ares, Athena or Hermes.  They each have their own skill tree, and you can choose to devote yourself to just one god, a few, or all.  The game does a poor job of introducing the system and I was at least half way through the game before I realized that I was never going to be able to get the higher level skills in any one deity's skill-tree, because I spent too much on low level skills on all of them.  The game also has "God Powers", which was even more confusing - I still have no idea how to use them.The item system is... almost non-existent.  You begin the game with a Shield, Armor, Mace, Sword and Spear.  You will always carry these items.  At certain points in the game you will gain upgrades to one or more of these items.  For instance, you'll get a new Mace that does more damage and/or adds a helpful effect to you or your allies during combat.  Curiously, the game will ask if you want to equip it to replace what you were using.  I have no idea why, the new weapons and armor are always better than the old.  It's very much 'Legend of Zelda' in terms of it's item-leveling.Which, brings me to a potential sore spot for some:  there is no item or inventory system.  There is no going to merchants and buying healing potions, weapons or armor.  There is no vendor system, there is no inventory system, and there is no objectives or journal system.  There is no opening of chests or bashing of barrels to find loot.  There is no looting of corpses, no thieving system, no lock-picking, no spell system, and you will never fire a bow.Because there is no journal or objectives system, you are left to your own wits in the game.  This is problematic, because even that is not enough if you're a completist who wants to finish all the "quests".  For instance, on Saria Island I couldn't read the first Herm (monument) when I got ashore.  It wasn't until later on the island that I attained a new party member who could read it.  I figured it could wait and I would read it on my way back to the boat.  I also gained a mission from the god Hermes to perform last rites on a number of deceased.  One of the dead's body was hanging for his crimes and I had to convince a particular NPC to release it, which is a dialogue puzzle I didn't complete before wrapping up a boss fight that propels the story and which made doing those two previously mentioned acts impossible, which meant two titles I could have used to appease the gods were gone too.  *sigh*  Be as thorough as you can, is my advice.While the game is linear and fails at most things RPG-related (no stat numbers to play with, no inventory, etc.), it does have a pretty solid story with lots of dialogue.  In fact, hilariously, some people hated this aspect of it, completely forgetting it's supposed to be an RPG.  Gamespot gave it a poor review, because the ignorant reviewer compared it to 'God of War' and complained there was not nearly enough combat.  That's like comparing apples with grapes and complaining you can't make raisins out of apples.  The dialogue, in fact, is the real high point of the game.  All the best stuff happens in the dialogue.  If you prefer games where mindless button-mashing is all you want, go play 'God of War'.The graphics in this game are beautiful.  The environments are detailed and enjoyable to play in.  The character models are all highly detailed and each has it's particular and unique style.  The characters are, of course, ridiculously sculpted and look like they all came from the He-Man universe.  The graphics won't win any awards today (this game came out in 2008), but just about everything is pleasing to the eye.  The biggest issue I have with this port of the game is that there are no graphic options to scale in the game, except for resolution.  This is disappointing, and frankly lazy.  This runs on the Unreal Engine, which is highly and easily scalable, so there really is no excuse for this. That reminds me, there is also no way to scale your mouse sensitivity.  The mouse is highly sensitive in this game and it took me an hour or so to get a grip on it.  You would be better off with a gamepad, but the controller support seems to be lacking.  It is said to support the Xbox 360 controller though.  The sound design is pretty spot on, and the voice-acting is top-notch.  My two favorite characters in the game are Pan and Achilles.  Pan is articulate and worldly.  Achilles is a narcissist and easily the funniest character in the game.  Be sure to take Achilles with you whenever you can, you won't regret it.There were some bugs in the game:  It once ate my save files, it crashes every once in awhile for no apparent reason, I hit a dialogue glitch with Daedalus (thankfully it didn't break anything), and in one or two instances I completed a fight but had to exit and load up a checkpoint save because a scripting bug prevented me from continuing to the next area (I'm thinking of the end sequence of the game).  The game also sometimes feels wanting:  you gain crew members for the Argo that ultimately feel unused, unnecessary, or just background dressing.Anyway, at the end of the day I would definitely recommend this.  It's not a long game, by RPG standards (10-15 hours), but it is highly entertaining.If you have framerate issues (you can also turn off vsynch in the same file):Go to My Documents/My Games/Rise of the Argonauts/LiquidGame/ConfigOpen the file LiquidEngine.ini (make a backup just to make sure) Change: OnlyStreamInTextures=FALSE into OnlyStreamInTextures=TRUE

												Rise of the Argonauts is a game that gets very little notice today. You play as Jason of Iolcus, king of ancient myth, whose wife Alceme is murdered by nefarious assassins. Instead of accepting her death, Jason sets out upon a journey across Greece in search of the one artifact that is reputedly able to reverse death: the Golden Fleece. Unique setting, fair graphics (Unreal 3), average voice-acting, good combat, and a fabulous soundtrack make this a niche classic.After the death of Alceme at the beginning, Jason must venture to several places, looking for clues to the location of the Golden Fleece. Three of these locations – Mycenae, Kythra, and Saria - can be visited in any order, so there is the possibility to take different squad-mates with you depending on where you visit first (you can take two for a party size of three). After everyone has been gathered, you have the location of the Golden Fleece, and proceed linearly to the end of the game. The areas and levels themselves are large, but not very open. Not that there would have been anything gained by a sandbox design; but the levels generally feel narrow and restricted, save for the wide open arenas where the fighting occurs.Rise of the Argonauts takes a serious, dramatic approach to Jason's classic tale. If that sounds like there is a lot of dialog in Rise of the Argonauts, there is. Everyone has conversation – and frequently, after finishing one discussion, you'll proceed to the next checkpoint only to have another conversation. There are branching dialog trees, and a few differing outcomes. But one place where Rise of the Argonauts falls beneath the others is in the quality of the voice-acting. It is serviceable, but not much else.The combat is swift and fun, and will leave you wishing for more. Jason keeps his shield, and can choose from a sword, spear, or mace. Slow-motion finishing moves abound. Enemies tend to be easy once you've mastered dodge and block. Each of the upgrade trees “honors” a different Greek god, and your combat develops in the manner your favored  god prefers. I choose Hermes for most of my upgrades, resulting in quick, active combat that favors the sword and allowed Jason to call down lightning strikes and great winds as he fought and dispatched enemies. Ares, Apollo and Athena each have their own styles, buffs and debuffs. Find the right balance, and combat can almost be too easy. Until you get to the boss battles, that is. Enjoy slicing and dicing the minor minions of the underworld while you can; there will come a time when you'll have to face  six minotaurs at once – while fighting a boss...Usually the soundtrack gets a passing mention of whether it is good or bad, but the music is one of the strongest parts of Rise of the Argonauts. Composer Tyler Bates channeled Troy and Gladiator and crafted a moving and intense score. There is a lot of fun to be had with Rise of the Argonauts if a dialogue-driven hack 'n slash piques your interest (as it did mine). The use of Greek legend provides a great ambiance, and unique ways to upgrade and play give it some replay value, too. An easy game to recommend if you are looking for a change of pace.

												I'm a sucker for ancient fables and had to try this game out because of the HumbleBundle. I recommend this game with EXTREME reservations. PROS:It has a good story, along with great voice acting and decent (if dated) graphics. Everything else is between bad and frustratingly bad, and I mean everything. CONS:The camera controls, especially on the final boss, made me realize how far we've come since it was released in 2008. The graphics are decent, but even my up to date PC had some stuttering issues when it loaded new areas. There is zero replay value in this game, unless you REALLY want to max out another skill tree. When you are running around, forget being able to roll, pull a weapon or do anything to break the monotony of each sandaled footfall - THE ONLY THINGS YOU CAN DO ARE RUN AND INTERACT WITH SPECIFIC OBJECTS. There is a LOT of running around in this game. So much running...and the map (at least using a 360 controller) is impossible to access without pausing the game and selecting the right option.The menus are unwieldy and slow and you are forced to use them for everything.There are no hidden items, no treasure chests.The only way to receive new equipment is to play through the dialogue selections correctly, wander into the right place, or simply progress the story. The entire game is on rails. Need to hide out behind a rock? Nope, you can't leave the path. Because you can't draw until there is a threat in front of you I frequently found myself surrounded by enemies before I was armed. That wasn't a problem because of my next point - WAY too easy. Anyone who wasn't a boss died by the truckload, leaving behind nothing because there are no items to pick up. The deaths were brutal and each weapon had at least two different ones but after the first chapter I'd seen them all.Too few types of enemies and again, I'd seen them all except the bosses by the end of the first level.tl:dr - Good story hack 'n slash with very little customization, replayability, or variety. Basically, if you want to see a slight twist on the story of the Argonauts you should check it out. If not, don't bother downloading all 12gb and thank me later.

The cities are amazing, you can see they wanted to give an "epic" ancient greek background and for most of the game it's actually a success. However, the port of the game from the console version makes it a really bad-optimized game and if you don't have a good computer you're going to endure lags and slowing down because there's NO MENU for the graphics settings, the resolution and such. The game looks good but at a price. b.Music and Voice Acting This is actually the best part of Rise of the Argonauts. The music is just fascinating, they tried to keep that "epic ancient greek atmosphere" but sometimes they add variations of other kind of musics like a tribal kind of sound when they arrive in a jungle or some dramatic chants when you arrive in ruins and/or dramatic part of the story. Voice acting is amazing, Jason is voiced by the incredible Brian Bloom (that is known for roles like Varric Tethras in dragon age and other series like COD or Silent Hill) that delivers a really convincing Jason that can deliver motivational speechs that gives you chills. You can also find Dave Fennoy (Lee Everett, Blue beard...) is the minor role of Daedalus. Overhall all the voicing of the game is good except for some NPC woman that just sound completly out of it.II.Content a.Gameplay Here's the worst part in my opinion. The gameplay could be devided in two phases, the first is exploring, talking, walking around the islands and solve people problems with a weel of choices. That weel of choices are based on four gods, Ares (violent, brutal), Hermes (Cunning, Sarcasm) Apollo (Kind, true) and Athena (Justice, serious), you will spend most of the time doing that. Each time you choose a perticular god answer, you gain favor for that god that can be use in a Skill tree, each skill tree offer bonuses for one weapon and gods power. Ares offers bonuses for the Maces, Hermes for the swords, Athena for the spears and Apollo for your shield. You can also gain favor by finishing quest and or killing a certain amount of enemy, once you did that you earn a title, you can then dedicate that title to one of the four gods and receive favor for that god. You can see all the titles that you can have in the "stars" map, each constellation is composed of stars that are lighten when you complete the task they ask. It's not a bad system at all but it could have been improve in a lots of ways.Anyway, what is really worse in my opinion is the combat system. It's just terrible. Sometimes you just have to mash the heavy attack button and execute your foe and sometimes, your spear just touch them and do nothing, when you're hit, your character falls in a awful way like no human could even do. The boss battles are just not that good, overall the combat is terrible and sometimes during the playthough I wanted fights so bad because I didn't had one in about an hour and then I get to the fights and wished they were over already, it's just weird whatever the weapon you choose. Also boss battle tried to use unique mecanics that no other foe use in the game and sometimes you just have to think to defeat them and it's good but sometimes it just make things worse. There's in the game, a boss that project ghost and that you need to reach to kill, once you hurt him enough he send you back to the start and you need to repeat, but the game combat system is so weird that when he shakes the ground to send you back at the start, your character fall like a lifeless pupett and even if you mash the button to get up he stays on the floor for a long time and get hit by ghosts that the enemy send without being able to move or defend himself it's horrible. Also Jason is not alone in his quest, you can recruit argonauts, what I thought would be amazing from the start, before I realize you recruit only 4 argonauts (like the 4 gods) in the whole game and it's a bit sad. I will come back to it in the writting section but I needed to mention them because you fight with them. Well the AI is not that smart but it's not annoying in the game except when you get to a particular place in the game where you need to kill the enemy out of the waters and that your two allies will always stay in the middle of the water no matter what. It's also a bit sad you can't equip or change in anyway the argonauts, I would have love to see Hercules change clothes since he stayed dirty with mud on him the whole game but it's okay.Jason can collect five of each type of weapon and armor, each with some power on them, it's interesting but personnaly I just put on him what looked the best. For me the gameplay is a bit of a let down because you need to do a lot of two-way trip, boss fight are not often enjoyable and sadly the game is short, you do the same thing on 5 Island and a special place (Exploring, talking, fighting) and some boss have to be done more than one time. I think the game had so much potential but this make it less good than it should be. b.Writting I saw a lot of people saying "If you like Mythology, it's a good game for you", well, not exactly, You can see big names of the mythology but there is a huge reinterpretation of everything.For exemple Pan devoted to Apollo when you know they have some kind of rivalry, or Medusa and Perseus in a weird Brother/Sister plot everything is messed up. Historical Accuracy is messed up too but it's hard to say the game is bad for that, you see, most of the mythological adaptation take liberties, it's like that and the important thing is to see if they hold things together on the run. Well they tried and it's okay, their liberties are huge but the whole thing is okay. A bit sad that the myth of Prometheus and Epimetheus has been a bit altered and Pandora is completely gone of the picture. I'm not going to criticize the choices for the mythology in the game anymore but I will talk about the writting of the story and the characters. The story is simple, Jason is the king of Iolcus lost his wife in a demonic attack, the gods (the four mentioned earlier) want to help him and give him some instruction, Jason takes the sea in the Argo and here it is the begining of the tale of "Jason and the Argonauts", You have to go to an Island, do some stuff for a god, go to the other search something until you find the golden fleece like in the legend. You can recruit four Argonauts and use two of them on each Island (when you have the choice and it's not always the case), each Argonauts is enjoyable in his own way, they all have a lot of personnality, however, this is ruined by how short the game is, for exemple one of the character has to discover the outside world but when you get that character, you almost visit nothing with her. That could have been so huge, so big as a secondary quest but instead the game says that everything happen after that. The whole plot of the game is simple but okay, side quest are either well written or forgetable, in any case the writting is not bad (maybe one death that was supposed to be sad but is just rushed since there's not enough talk with that character to get attach to it) III.Othersa.Replay Value Even with the choices, the game is pretty much the same every time you play it, you can choose to kill or spare a few foes but that's all. 												A fun fantasy RPG set in Ancient Greece and follows a quest of King Jason and the Argo crew in search of the Golden Fleece. I was surprised to find out that the game was released back in 2008, considering how good it looks for its time. The story takes you to a number of locations, in which you acquire some new party members and other allies to help you on your quest. 3 of the major locations in the middle part of the game can be done in any order of preference. The gameplay consists of combat sections, exploration sections, and dialogue/role-playing sections.Combat is really well done. You are able to swap between using a mace, a sword, and a spear, and each one has their own combos and special abilities. The special abilities and various passive bonuses are learned from skill progression trees attributed to 4 different Greek deities: Ares, Hermes, Apollo, and Athena. Overall the feel of combat is very fluid and visceral. Enemies get their heads popped by mace swings or get sliced in half by a sword, and so on. Only thing I wasn't too fond of were the boss fights. They weren't terrible, but most of them were somewhat frustrating and at times even cheap. A few required you to do something very unique and unintuitive, and hence a solution would be unclear.The rest of the game you'd spend exploring the locations and completing quests, some of which are optional, but completing them gains you additional weapon choices or pieces of armour. There are a lot of the dialogue sections in the game where you get to make decisions and choose how you respond. Even if a dialogue choice doesn't have any consequences, it still has an alignment with one of the four deities, and acquiring a certain number of deity-aligned choices nets you a skill point to spend in their skill tree.Overall it's a pretty fun adventure RPG and anyone who likes Greek mythology should give it a try. It does change some of the stories and characters from the myths slightly, but it's still done in a fresh and engaging manner to keep things interesting. I'll recommend this game. It's quite underrated.I've done a 19-part let's play video series on Youtube of me playing the game with live voice commentary in case you're interested to see more of the game:

												Rise of the Argonauts is a good game, one which has a number of great ideas, but most of them fall a bit short, making the result come just a bit short of being an excellent game, though still a very enjoyable one.I would say the basic idea the devs had was to make a story-driven, hack'n'slash action RPG, and in the end, apart from the RPG part which is great and unique, the other parts are weirdly meshed together and kind of underdevelpoped.Let's start with the story, which tells a slightly modified version of the Greek legend of Jason and the Argonauts. In this version, Jason's bride Alceme is killed during their wedding, and Jason sets out to find the Golden Fleece in order to bring her back to life. The story is pretty straightforward, and being based on preexisting lore, you can immediately tell what will happen. But the writers manage to keep you invested with a number of interesting characters from Greek mythology whom Jason encounters along the way, and having all the elements you want from a Greek legend. You travel various colorful locations, meet and fight alongside heroes of legend, slay great beasts, and even take part in a philosophical debate(in my opinion, one of the best sections of the game).Combat is your standard action h'n's deal. Light attack, heavy attack, dodge, block, parry. You have three weapons, a sword, a mace and a spear, each with its own strengths, weaknesses and a distinct playstyle. You can switch them on the fly, and over the course of your journey you will find better weapons, even ones blessed by the gods themselves which have special properties. The combat is pretty good, but it is way too easy. Even on hard, the game is ridiculously easy, unless you refuse to level up, in which case it gets boring, not hard, because you lack the damage to kill enemies with more health while being able to dodge all of their attacks.Now, a bit on the RPG elements of the game, its by far best segment. This game has a really unique way of leveling up. Jason is favored by four gods: Ares, Apollo, Hermes and Athena. During conversations, all of your choices are favored by a certain god. Choosing one will grant you favor with that god, and once you accumulate enough favor, you earn an aspect point you can then invest in that god's skill tree. Also, the game keeps track of your deeds, which are a sort of achievements. You can devote these deeds to the gods in exchange for favor. It is a really unique take on XP, and I enjoyed it quite a lot. Also, the skills are varied and interesting, with each god granting you skills and powers which favor a certain playstyle reflective of his or her field of dominion.Having discussed the three main aspect of the mix of genres this game covers, it's time to talk about how they work together, which is a bit...meh. The game's pacing and story/combat balance is really, really bad. There are lengthy sections where you do no combat at all, followed by either a short battle or a long, drawn out sequence of battles where enemies just keep on coming for you to oneshot. The story and combat don't really work together, they seem more like being thrown in together.This is one of those cases where the whole is better than the sum of its parts. Though all of these elements have great ideas but more of an ok execution, and even work to mixed results together, the game as a whole is still really enjoyable. I had a blast with it, and the 12 hours I put in just flew by. Even with the easy combat, and bad pacing, I was never actually bored, and almost burned through it, without even noticing that I had played for that long, which is not something I can say for many other games.Despite its flaws, I would highly recommend the game, especially if you are a fan of Greek mythology. You may not get the greatest of stories, or challenging combat, but you can have a great time, which shows that with fresh ideas, even an ok game can be a great experience.

												This is a game that had great potential. Despite some of the technical faults it manages to deliver an amazing experience.If you like Jade Empire then you will love this game. It is a real Role Playing game, without having Level or XP. You play the role of an Ancient Hero, Figter and King. You find companions, make friends and enemies. Gods offer you powers. You don't simply become 10 times stronger because you killed 100 rats. The improvements are incremental, you can see them and enjoy them.  There are no heal potions or inventory.The combat is really satisfying, focused on melee combos and the strengths and trade-offs of your 3 weapons. The Mace, Spear and Sword. Your shield is always at your side. The other aspect of the game is the dialog. The choices you make affect part of the storyline and is just an opportunity to pick your style without having to overthink the consequences. Just enjoy them. The story is good and the characters develop in a very interesting way. It took me 20 hours to finish the game (one playtrough on Legend), and now that I finished it I want more. I could play easily another 20 hours, another 3-4 cities, another campaign. Unfortunately there is little replay value once you finish it once, but just the fact that I mention this means it was worth the first one. The end-game is simply amazing. When you meet the Oracle of Depli for the second time, make sure you have a free evening because you won't be putting the controller down until the credits roll. Simply not happening. The epilogue is simply incredible.When the game starts the combat feels a bit awkward. That's because of the tutorial and some of the combos being disabled until about the first 40 minutes of gameplay. The game really only starts after you leave the palace. Make sure to keep playing passed this initial phase and not judge the game based on the first 5 minutes of gameplay. Trust me a fantastic experience awaits.The greatest enemy in the game is alas the crashes. The game crashed for me no matter what I tried to do. However I did finish it. Use the checkpoint system to your advantage, a crash can only set you back a few minutes if you make sure to change area after every major cutscene, before you engage in more dialog. One design complain is about the map. The map should be accessible from a single button, and some form of minimap should let you go to your next objective. Finally a special mention to the music of the game composed by Tyler Bates, simply incredible. Check for it online. Do I recommend this game? **** YEAH!

content:
Posted: April 14
												This game is an adventure game/action RPG set in ancient Greece in which you play the role of Jason, king and warden of Iolcus under the protection of Zeus himself. That sets the tone for the story. It's definitely a setting in which being a hero actually means something. The game itself is served by serviceable combat mechanics which are pretty common when it comes to hack and slash games at best it will remind you of a game like Kingdoms of Amalur but most of the time you can get by with simply mashing buttons (apart from the boss fights which will require you to study your foe to understand the pattern used by the boss to defeat him or her which is pretty standard gaming practice anyway). Some finishing moves are nice to behold and give a heroic feel to the fights. The game may not look incredibly good for 2017 and some of the textures can be a bit blurry but considering it was released in 2008 it's definitely not terrible and more importantly the art direction is rather solid with some nice touches in the background and a consistent use of assets in environments. Some faces seem to be recycled a bit too much but others really stand out in a good way. Animations are fine but they probably won't keep you up at night either. Foes usually look good and if you're into sandals you will probably like the way the main character looks (before playing this game I had no idea they made bikini armours for guys and Jason clearly likes showing his six pack abs so that may be a plus for the ladies). Voice acting is mostly good and sometimes excellent and the music is simply incredible. It sets the tone and give an epic vibe to the game (which doesn't come as a surprise considering that the composer was responsible for the music for the movie 300 and arguably the music wasn't the worst or the most controversial part). A great soundtrack is an important feature and that's an area in which this game shines. Considering the lack of games set in ancient mythic Greece especially when it comes to games that actually try to tell a story (I've enjoyed Titan Quest but it wasn't for the story) Rise of the Argonauts is an interesting title. It gets even better when it becomes obvious that despite its linearity (the game opens up a bit just like Bioware games in which you can explore several areas in a different sequence) it's actually a pretty good story for any fan of Greek mythology and computer RPGs. Of course the game takes some liberties with the myths and that can be irksome if you're a purist some of these changes annoyed me at first until I came to accept that the game was trying to keep things fresh and after a while I came to terms with that. The name dropping may annoy you and the fact that Achilles was supposed to be a baby at the time when Jason set off for his quest may annoy you just like the fact that some characters have slightly different roles like for instance Medea or even Perseus. In any case the writing is really good and there is plenty of dialogue (probably too much for some players) so it's a game that will require some patience and that may explain why it didn't do so well.What sets the game apart is the way experience is handled. After completing a quest or an achievement you get a deed that you can dedicate to a particular deity which allows you to get some points to buy skills in that god's skill tree. Each skill tree is focused on a different weapon type the mace, the spear, the sword and the shield so there is an incentive in focusing on a particular god. During dialogues you usually have four choices which are symbolized by a different icon so you can pick your lines by following a god's attitude for a particular situation. You have Ares (violent and brutal but straightforward and honest), Athena (mostly the just and sensible one but also the one who goes by the book), Apollo (compassionate, fair and dignified but also sometimes a bit proud) and Hermes (full of guile, mischief but also clever and manipulative). It gives some great flavour to the game. Quests make you feel like your choices actually matter which is good but in the end you're still moving along the main quest so it may be more of an illusion. Still the game offers enough leeway to actually feel less linear than it is and that's something that is really nice. Bottom line it's a good title for CRPG players who thirst for a mythological setting, it's not perfect (some backtracking is involved at times and there isn't much in the way of exploration) but it's much better than what the critics gave it credit for especially if you value the story above the rest. There is a caveat though and that's the fact that the game tends to crash a lot simply because it has to be run on a single core on modern computers. I used to have some pretty regular crashes but the game has been running very smoothly ever since I switched to a single core.

												I really enjoyed Rise of the Argonauts. Yes, it's quite easy and not very long, the plot is kind of stupid in places, the loading times disguised as cutscenes (I'm talking to you, gates to the Acropolis of Mycenae) become tedious because there's much running back and forth, and it's not the best looking game out there. Why did I like it then?Well, I'm a sucker for Greek mythology and I think this game gets the atmosphere right. Mostly. Don't get me wrong, the legendary characters, places and stories of old are misplaced, mixed and butchered without remorse, when not completely made up. If you want a more canonical depiction of Greek myths go play Apotheon (seriously, go play it, it's awesome!), this is more like a fanfiction or an alternate reality but still feels Greek and mythological enough.I specially like the god alignment system. Dialog options don't influence the plot but they do influence gameplay because your dialog choices are aligned with one of four deities (Athena, Apollo, Ares and Hermes). Winning their favour by choosing their dialogs or dedicating your deeds (ingame achievements) to them lets you level up in their respective skill trees and unlock different powers and buffs. To me it feels very satisfying to devote yourself to a god (Athena rules and anyone who disagrees will eat my spear), it really gets me immersed.The dialogs and characters are mostly well written. Each of your companions have different personalities, and they interact between them and with the enviroment in different ways (Pan is snarky and will go on about old legends and trivia, Achilles is obnoxious and will brag about being the best fighter ever, and so on). Like Mass Effect, you take your ship (the Argo, a steampunk-ish mechanical Greek galley) to different locations and decide which companions will go ashore with you. Of course it's much more limited and samll than Mass Effect, with only five or six main locations or so, and only four companions to choose from, although you collect a few other characters with whom you can speak while on board the Argo.The combat, although not very tricky, is fluid, fun and bloody, and can get quite spectacular once you start throwing god powers all over the place.Aesthetically, it's good enough. Some of the enviroments look pretty and colorful, like Iolcus palace (I really liked the guards openning the doors for you, I know it's probably there just to hide a loading time but it made me feel like a king and I've seen too many magical self-openning doors in games to appreciate the detail), while others are much more dull and uninspired. The bronze in your armour is shiny and many of the armours and wepons themselves are not too overly fantastical in design, which I like.I haven't experienced crashes or major bugs that I remember, as many reviews say, and I played for several hours at a time. I guess I got lucky. I bough this game on a sale for dirt cheap (1.75 EUR) fearing that it would be awful or crash on me, but I was pleasantly surprised and, after completing it, I woudn't mind having paid more for it.

												Rise of the Argonauts is an action rpg set in ancient Greece.  You play the mythical hero Jason in search of the golden fleece, in an adventure filled with Greek mythology.  The story was entertaining and I enjoyed the recreation of ancient grease, it made the game seem more weighty than the typical fantasy fair, being grounded in earth history.  Gameplay wise it consists of lots of interesting conversations and side quests, as well as typical rock paper scissors combat.  There are several distinct play styles in combat which made for a nice change of pace.  There is plenty of choice in the conversations, but instead of the typically good vs bad vs neutral conversations trees this game basis the conversation topics on different gods.  Each of the 4 gods has a level up tree where you open up new abilities and bluffs, the deeds you complete and conversation choices you makes fills the appropriates God’s tree.  It’s a fresh and different take on conversation and quests and I really enjoyed this aspect of the game.Overall I really enjoyed my time with Jason and his Argonauts.  Unfortunately I can’t recommend this game as during conversations it kept randomly crashing to desktop.  It started periodically at first, and then grew in rate to the point of crashing every few conversations, making the game basically unplayable.  I tried a few of the fixes I found in steam forums and online but none of it solved the crashing.  Overall Rise of the Argonauts is a really great hidden Gem RPG, but it’s very buggy to the point of being unplayable.  A search of the forums in steam will show I am far from the only one with this experience.

However, I can't recommend it given how most of the game is spent in boring conversations. If there had been more action, I would recommend it, but sadly, there isn't enough to keep the game interesting.I also encountered frequent crashes at seemingly random points, but I can't say for sure if it's the game or my computer. However given that i can play more recent and far more graphically demanding titles than this, it seems likely that it's the game that's at fault.

												I really, really wanted to like this game.  It shows so much promise, but for every step forward, it takes 3 steps backwards.First, the game is a beautiful reimagining of the Greek myth of the Argonauts and the Golden Fleece.  The art direction is absolutely gorgeous - the environments are great, your armor and weapons look unique and interesting, and all the characters manage to look "larger than life" while still fitting into the game world.  The main characters, that is, because there are only 3 NPC models in this game.  At one point, I was mediating a dispute between three merchants, and they were all the same person.  It really breaks immersion to walk through a city full of clones.The writing is really well done, and the conversation system (where you can pick responses that align with certain gods - like a witty response to appeal to Hermes or an aggressive response for Ares) works very well!  But NPCs converse by stiffly holding the same pose and moving only their mouth, or repeating the same hand motion over and over, which is often distracting, sometimes unsettling.The combat just kinda sucks, really.  I like that you can switch between the Spear, Sword, and Mace, but they all play the same: just wail on your enemy until it dies.  There's not strategy, it's just button mashing.  It's also a real tragedy that there's a finite number of enemies in this game, and it's VERY POSSIBLE for your Argonaut allies to steal enough kills and prevent you from reaching max exp.  So you get these really well crafted characters, but just end up resenting them for stealing your kills.  Plus, the lack of a lock-on systems is BS, I can't count how many times I've whittled an enemy down to kill him with a thrown spear, only to have my character do a 180 and throw it at someone offscreen.  Then one of my allies kills the weakened enemy, because of course.The cherry on the top is that this game is an abysmal port.  Apart from screen resolution, there's no visual settings at all, not even a LOW, MEDIUM, HIGH option.  Plus, frequent crashes to desktop, which are inexcusable in my opinion.It's a little embarrasing.  This game could have been great - like, legitimately great, but they ♥♥♥♥ed it up so bad, I'm kind of amazed actually.  I wish I could recommend this game, but I can't.  Watch a youtube playthrough, though, because the story is pretty grand.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------EDIT:  Having played the game to completion, I'm now fully qualified to say this game is absolute trash.Despite all the good things I said about it in my original review, my feelings about the game as the end credits rolled were overwhelmingly negative.  The developer, Liquid Entertainment, should be ashamed of themselves that they took something with so much promise and potential and made it so irredemably terrible.  Whatever good qualities this game has are so thoroughly drenched in filth, it's really not worth a playthrough to experience them.Don't buy this.

												Basically you are doing lots of talking and walking around with some combat mixed in.The combat consists of using three weapons (sword, spear and mace), each with a primary and secondary attack, as well as a special attack. Additionally you can block attacks and bash enemies with your shield. Finally you can dodge attacks and use "god powers", which are unlocked through a skill tree.The skill system seems to be the game's most unique aspect. You fulfill deeds, e.g. "Killed 10 enemies with a sword" or "Made 10 choices aligned with Athene". Each deed is worth a certain amount of XP and can be dedicated to one of four gods (aka skilltrees). With enough experience in one tree, passive skills as well as active "god powers" can be unlocked. Reskilling is not possible.Positive PointsGraphics are good.Dialogs and story is decent enough (but not historically correct).Performance is no issue.Loading times are short.Combat is quite enjoyable.Interesting skill system.Negative PointsNo real graphics options whatsoever. They are however available via ".ini"-files.The game frequently (about once an hour) crashes/freezes in random situations.Combined with the checkpoint system (no quick save/load) this can be really annoying.At various places barriers are placed which you have to wait for opening.The game's menu is badly optimized for keyboard/mouse control.SummaryI'm going to finish playing this game, but can only recommend it to players which are not annoyed by its negative aspects.

												Is this the best game in the world? Nah. But it really is a GREAT game. I'm bothered a lot about gameplay getting in the way of the story; that does NOT happen here. The gameplay is quick to pick up and fairly intuitive. There's very little HUD (practically none), and each encounter is carefully planned/placed and makes perfect sense. It never feels like grinding.Storywise, it's a very rich game. If you love Greek mythology you'll have a fun time with how Rise of the Argonauts plays with it. My one complaint is that the story is very "plain." There are a few chances to complicate the narrative that are just passed by (the oracle, for instance, clearly switches between the maid, matron, and crone in her speech. Or as the Moirai, Clotho, Lachesis, and Atropos. In either case it was a fun opportunity to make the character a bit more three-dimensional) but by and large this same plainness is done SO WELL that it really works for the game. The graphics are dated, but they work well for the game as a whole. I finished the game at just over 10 hours on normal difficulty. I wasn't a super-completionist (can't be bothered) but I can't imagine it being much longer even if I were. I really only had trouble with a FEW battles but otherwise it was intuitive enough I didn't have to look up help.
